metadata.title: Changes ‚Äì Physical and Chemical
metadata.subject: Science
metadata.description: This chapter explains the difference between physical and chemical changes, how to identify them, and gives real-life examples of both types of changes observed in everyday life.

preAssessment.question: Which of the following is a physical change?
Which of the following is a chemical change?
In a chemical change, is it easy to get back the original substance?
What is the chemical name for rusting of iron?
Which of the following is NOT a sign of a chemical change?

concepts.title: Physical Changes
concepts.content: A physical change is a change in the physical properties of a substance (shape, size, state) without forming any new substance. Physical changes are usually reversible ‚Äî the original substance can be recovered.

examples.text: Ice melting into water ‚Äî water can be frozen back to ice
Cutting paper into pieces ‚Äî same paper, different shape
Dissolving salt in water ‚Äî salt can be recovered by evaporation

keyPoints.text: No new substance is formed in a physical change
Changes in state (solid-liquid-gas) are physical changes

concepts.funFact: When you crumple a piece of aluminium foil, that's a physical change! You can flatten it back out ‚Äî the aluminium itself hasn't changed.

concepts.title: Chemical Changes
concepts.content: A chemical change results in the formation of one or more new substances with different properties from the original. Chemical changes are usually irreversible and involve energy changes (heat, light, sound produced or absorbed).

examples.text: Burning a candle ‚Äî wax is converted to CO2 and water vapour
Curdling milk ‚Äî proteins change structure, cannot become fresh milk again
Cooking food ‚Äî raw vegetables become cooked, properties change permanently

keyPoints.text: A new substance with different properties is always formed
Usually irreversible ‚Äî original substance hard to recover
Signs include: colour change, gas produced, heat/light released, precipitate formed

concepts.funFact: Baking a cake is a chemical change! The raw batter undergoes chemical reactions when heated and can never turn back into uncooked batter.

concepts.title: Rusting and Corrosion
concepts.content: Rusting is the chemical change where iron reacts with oxygen and water to form iron oxide (rust). It is a slow chemical change. Corrosion is the deterioration of metals due to chemical reactions with their environment.

examples.text: Old iron gates and railings turning red-brown due to rusting
Steel bridges being painted to prevent rust
Copper vessels turning green due to corrosion (verdigris)

keyPoints.text: Rusting requires both oxygen and water (moisture)
Prevention methods: painting, oiling, galvanising, electroplating
Galvanising means coating iron with zinc to prevent rust

concepts.funFact: The Eiffel Tower in Paris is repainted every 7 years using 60 tonnes of paint to prevent rust ‚Äî it would weigh less without paint!

concepts.title: Identifying Physical vs Chemical Changes
concepts.content: The key to identifying a chemical change is to look for signs of a new substance being formed. Physical changes only alter the appearance or state, while chemical changes produce substances with completely different properties.

examples.text: Water boiling (physical) vs electrolysis of water into hydrogen and oxygen (chemical)
Sugar dissolving (physical) vs sugar burning to form black carbon (chemical)
Tearing paper (physical) vs burning paper to form ash (chemical)

keyPoints.text: Ask: Is a new substance formed? ‚Üí Chemical change
Ask: Can the original substance be recovered? ‚Üí Physical change if yes
Energy changes (heat, light, sound) suggest chemical change

concepts.funFact: Digestion in our body is a chemical change ‚Äî enzymes break down food into completely different molecules that our cells can use as energy!

concepts.title: Uses of Chemical Changes
concepts.content: Chemical changes are used extensively in everyday life and industry ‚Äî from cooking food to manufacturing medicines, plastics, cement, and fertilisers. Controlled chemical changes power our vehicles and generate electricity.

examples.text: Burning petrol/diesel in vehicle engines ‚Äî combustion provides energy for movement
Making cement ‚Äî limestone is heated to produce calcium oxide and CO2
Photography ‚Äî silver halide crystals undergo chemical changes when exposed to light

keyPoints.text: Combustion (burning) is a key chemical change that releases energy
Fermentation is a chemical change used to make bread, idli, and wine
Photosynthesis and respiration are chemical changes in living things

concepts.funFact: The 'new car smell' comes from chemical changes ‚Äî volatile organic compounds released as plastics and synthetic materials undergo slow chemical reactions!

test.question: Which of the following is a reversible physical change?
test.explanation: Melting wax is a physical change because the wax can be cooled and solidified again without forming a new substance.

test.question: What are the signs that a chemical change has occurred?
options: New substance formed with different properties
test.explanation: The definitive sign of a chemical change is the formation of a new substance with different properties from the original.

test.question: Rusting of iron is an example of:
test.explanation: Rusting is a chemical change because iron reacts with oxygen and water to form iron oxide ‚Äî a completely new substance.

test.question: Which method prevents rusting of iron?
test.explanation: Rust requires both oxygen and moisture. Keeping iron dry or painting it prevents contact with water, preventing rusting.

test.question: Dissolving common salt in water is a:
test.explanation: Dissolving salt in water is a physical change ‚Äî the salt can be recovered by evaporating the water.

test.question: In which of these is a new substance definitely formed?
test.explanation: Burning a matchstick produces ash, smoke, and gases ‚Äî completely new substances. The original matchstick cannot be recovered.

test.question: What is galvanisation?
test.explanation: Galvanisation is the process of coating iron or steel with a layer of zinc to protect it from rusting.

test.question: Cooking food is a chemical change because:
options: New substances are formed and it cannot be reversed
test.explanation: Cooking causes chemical reactions that create new substances and change the properties of food permanently ‚Äî cooked rice cannot become raw rice.

commonMisconceptions: Colour change always means chemical change ‚Äî dissolving coloured substances is physical
All chemical changes release heat ‚Äî some absorb heat (endothermic)
Dissolving is a chemical change ‚Äî it is physical as the substance can be recovered
realWorldExamples: Galvanised iron sheets on rooftops in India
